udl.title: UNDERSTANDING DEEP LEARNING 2024
udl.description: Join us in October for a series of online lectures featuring renowned researchers from the world's leading universities and institutions, discussing the latest advancements in Deep Learning.
udl.dateDetails: From October 14 to 18, 2024, for an in-depth exploration of Deep Learning, covering topics such as LLM's, Graph Neural Networks, Topological Deep Learning, Reinforcement Learning, and Deep Learning applications at the forefront of science.

speakers.title: Renowned International Speakers
speakers.description: Listen to experts from MIT, Cambridge, UC Santa Barbara, Purdue University, University of Amsterdam and institutions such as DeepMind and Cohere. Cutting-edge insights from the top AI specialists.

about.title: ABOUT THE EVENT
about.description: UnderstandingDL 2024 is an international event organized by the Data Group at USP São Carlos, from the Institute of Mathematical and Computer Sciences (ICMC). It is dedicated to the study and dissemination of knowledge in Data Science to both internal and external audiences.
about.details: The event aims to bring together researchers from around the world to present their work and make knowledge more accessible to everyone. Topics covered in the lectures include Multilingual LLMs, Multi-resolution Image Representation using Neural Networks, among many others.
about.sponsors: UnderstandingDL 2024 aims to highlight researchers and their contributions. Groups like Brains and C4AI support and sponsor the event, along with the backing of Latin America's largest university, the University of São Paulo.

sponsors.title: Sponsors
sponsors.subtitle: Institutions that believe in the project

questions.location: Where is the event being held?

log.title: LEARNING ON GRAPHS CONFERENCE 2025
log.description: Join us on May 10 and 11 to dive into the world of one of the most important and exciting areas of Artificial Intelligence: Graph Machine Learning!
log.dateDetails: May 10 and 11, 2025, for an immersion in Graph Machine Learning featuring lectures, mini-courses, and sessions for presenting academic papers.

lectures.title: High-level Lectures and Mini-courses
lectures.description: With Brazilian researchers from renowned institutions in Brazil and around the world, learn more about the theory of Graph Machine Learning and its diverse applications, such as Computer Vision, Ocean Modeling, and Healthcare.

research.title: Showcase Your Research
research.description: Undergraduate, Master's, and PhD students from Brazilian universities researching the topic can showcase their work in our in-person poster session or our online Flash Talks session. Registration for both activities is open until May 3.

about.title: ABOUT THE EVENT
about.description: Founded in 2022, the Learning on Graphs Conference (LoG) is the world's premier academic conference dedicated to Graph Machine Learning. Each year the conference features a main event along with a network of local meetings around the globe. Now, on May 10 and 11, 2025, São Carlos will be the first city in Latin America and the Southern Hemisphere to host a LoG meeting.
about.details: The goal of LoG São Carlos is to boost Brazilian research in Graph Learning through an event conducted in Portuguese, featuring Brazilian speakers or experts with extensive involvement in the country, and providing spaces to showcase Brazilian academic work on the subject. It is an opportunity to promote Brazilian science in the field, disseminating ongoing research and offering enriching learning experiences for the development of researchers and other professionals.

historyCTA.text: Want to learn more about LoG's history?

saturday.title: Graph Learning in Healthcare: From GNNs to Integration with LLMs
saturday.speaker: Heloisa Oss Boll
saturday.description: The lecture will address advanced techniques for deep patient representation, focusing on predicting clinical outcomes from electronic health records (EHRs) using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). In conclusion, recent methods integrating biomedical knowledge graphs with large language models (LLMs) will be explored, expanding support for clinical reasoning.

saturday.title: Mastering Scene Understanding: Scene Graphs to the Rescue
saturday.description: Scene understanding tasks in computer vision have seen remarkable advances in recent years. This presentation highlights the contribution of developing scene graphs and their well-structured, semantic representations. Such an approach allows for better contextual comprehension and facilitates tasks like image description, generation, search, as well as identifying human-object interactions and answering visual questions. The session explores current research on scene graphs, including methods, applications, databases, and future perspectives.

saturday.title: Pattern-based Classification and the Development of New GNNs
saturday.speaker: Zhao Liang
saturday.description: Traditional data classification relies only on physical attributes such as distance, similarity, or distribution, which is considered low-level classification. In contrast, the human (or animal) brain learns at both low and high levels, recognizing patterns based on the semantic meaning of data. This lecture will introduce approaches for implementing pattern-based learning and discuss the development of new Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) through the application of complex network theory.

saturday.title: Poster Session
saturday.description: Undergraduate, Master's, and PhD students will have the opportunity to showcase their research in Graph Machine Learning in-person at ICMC. Registration is open until May 3.

sunday.title: The Age of Complexity
sunday.speaker: Francisco Rodrigues
sunday.description: Climate change, economic crises, epidemics, social inequality, and the rising mental health crisis are among humanity's most urgent challenges. How can science help understand and address these issues? This lecture explores how complex network theory, combined with machine learning and deep learning techniques, can offer new perspectives on these problems. We will discuss applications of networks in diagnosing mental disorders, predicting droughts and climate change, modeling the global economy, and analyzing social network dynamics.

sunday.title: Graph-Based Deep Learning for Ocean Modeling: Methods and Offshore Applications
sunday.speaker: Marcel Barros
sunday.description: This seminar provides an overview of cutting-edge methodologies in graph-based deep learning applied to the complex field of ocean modeling. We will explore techniques such as Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), Graph Transformers, and multi-mesh approaches used to capture intricate ocean dynamics, handle sparse and irregular data from various sources (including time series, satellite images, and physical models), and effectively propagate information over large spatial scales. Additionally, the integration of physics-informed machine learning principles within graph-based frameworks will be discussed to ensure physical consistency, enhance generalization capabilities, and enable resolution-invariant predictions. The presentation contextualizes these methods within the Digital Transformation Project of the Offshore Technology Innovation Center (OTIC) and the Numerical Test Tank (TPN-USP), demonstrating how these advanced graph-based models are being developed and applied to meet critical offshore industry demands, such as robust meteo-ocean forecasts, environmental monitoring, estimation of hidden variables, and the optimization of operations for safety and efficiency.

sunday.title: Mini-course - Introduction to Graph Neural Networks
sunday.speaker: Marcos Gôlo
sunday.description: Graph Neural Networks have become prominent in various areas of machine learning, including social network analysis, computational chemistry, recommendation systems, and natural language processing. Modeling data as graphs allows for incorporating multiple feature modalities, creating richer and more informative representations, as well as efficiently capturing relationships between data. In this mini-course, we will explore techniques for modeling unstructured data using graphs, delve into representation learning through graph neural networks, and discuss the advantages of this approach and its applications in machine learning. Fundamental concepts of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), along with popular variants such as Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs), will be presented. The course also includes practical demonstrations for transductive node classification based on a real-world problem, enabling participants to experiment with and implement the discussed concepts.

sunday.title: Open Flash Talks Session
sunday.description: Open to participants from all over Brazil, the Flash Talks session is a space where undergraduate, Master's, and PhD students can present their research projects on Graph Machine Learning in 5-minute talks. Registration is open until May 3.

list.name: Marcos Gôlo
list.bio: Marcos Gôlo holds a master's degree in computer science from the Institute of Mathematical and Computer Sciences at the University of São Paulo, São Carlos campus. Marcos explored multimodal representation learning in textual data for one-class learning during his master's with papers published in national conferences and international journals. Additionally, Marcos received the award for the second best master's thesis in the thesis and dissertation contest (CTD) at CSBC 2023 and the best dissertation at the CTD at Webmedia 2023. Currently, he is pursuing a doctorate at the same place as his master's, was awarded the Latin American Google PhD Fellowship to research representation learning in heterogeneous graphs in one-class learning, and is conducting a sandwich doctorate in Leipzig, Germany. Marcos has interests in the research areas of data mining, text mining, one-class learning, and representation learning in graphs.

list.name: Carlos Caetano
list.bio: Carlos Caetano holds a PhD in Computer Science from the Federal University of Minas Gerais (UFMG), with part of his studies conducted at the Centre de Recherche INRIA Sophia Antipolis, France, as a researcher in the STARS team. He holds a master's degree in Computer Science from the same university and a bachelor's degree in Information Systems from the Pontifical Catholic University of Minas Gerais (PUC Minas). Carlos worked as a researcher in Artificial Intelligence and a Machine Learning specialist at Samsung Research Development Institute Brazil (SRBR). Currently, he is a scientific researcher in post-doctorate at the State University of Campinas (UNICAMP), integrating the Artificial Intelligence laboratory Recod.ai. His research covers areas such as Computer Vision, Digital Image Processing, Image and Video Classification, and Signal Processing.

list.name: Marcel Barros
list.bio: PhD in Electrical Engineering from the University of São Paulo, with emphasis on Computer Engineering. His doctoral research focused on temporal encoding techniques for multivariate time series, involving graph-based models. He holds a degree in Electrical Engineering with emphasis on Computing from the same institution (2011). He is currently a researcher at the Numerical Test Tank (TPN-USP), working on projects in partnership with Petrobras, and at the Offshore Technology Innovation Centre (OTIC), on projects in partnership with Shell. He works with machine learning applications for offshore engineering, with a special focus on modeling meteorological and oceanographic variables.

list.name: Leo Sampaio
list.bio: Professor at ICMC-USP. She obtained her PhD in Computer Sciences from ICMC-USP and was a postdoctoral researcher at the State University of Campinas (Unicamp). She works as a researcher in the field of Computer Vision, with specific experience in the development of multimodal models focused on cross-domain search. In addition to the multimodal search problem, the researcher also works on recognizing sensitive content under few-data protocols and domain generalization.

list.name: Heloisa Oss Boll
list.bio: PhD candidate at the University of Amsterdam/Amsterdam UMC, where she researches deep learning methods with a focus on graphs and natural language processing (NLP) applied to the Dutch healthcare system. She holds a master's degree in Computer Science from INF-UFRGS, specializing in Artificial Intelligence for healthcare. Her dissertation focused on using graph neural networks (GNN) and electronic health records (EHR) for clinical risk prediction. Her main research interests involve the use of deep learning and multimodal data to improve patient care.

list.name: Zhao Liang
list.bio: He obtained his bachelor's degree from Wuhan University, China, in 1988 and completed his master's and doctoral degrees in Computer Science at the Technological Institute of Aeronautics (ITA) in 1996 and 1998, respectively. In 2000, he joined the faculty of the Institute of Mathematical and Computer Sciences (ICMC) of the University of São Paulo (USP), located in São Carlos. He currently holds the position of Full Professor in the Department of Computing and Mathematics (DCM), at the Faculty of Philosophy, Science, and Letters of Ribeirão Preto (FFCLRP) of USP.

list.name: Francisco Rodrigues
list.bio: Francisco A. Rodrigues is a full professor at the Institute of Mathematical and Computer Sciences (University of São Paulo), working in the area of Complex Systems and Data Science. Currently, he is the head of the Department of Applied Mathematics. He was a visiting professor at the University of Warwick (United Kingdom) between 2018 and 2019 with funding from the Leverhulme Trust. He was a visiting researcher (short term) at Universidad de Zaragoza (Spain), at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Research (Germany), and at the Complexity Science Hub Vienna (Austria). He was also a visiting professor at Aschaffenburg University of Applied Sciences (Germany) and Universidad de Zaragoza.

questions.language: Will the event be in Portuguese?
questions.language_answer: Yes, the entire event program will be in Portuguese. To allow people from other countries to watch the lectures, recordings will also be available with English subtitles.
questions.free_answer: Yes, the event is completely free!
questions.location: Where is the event being held?
questions.location_answer: The event will take place at ICMC - USP (the location for each activity can be found in the event schedule). Additionally, the lectures, mini-courses, and Flash Talks will be broadcast live on Data's YouTube channel.
questions.certificate_answer: Yes, a certificate is provided for those who register for the event and attend at least three lectures or mini-courses. Additionally, special certificates will be issued for those who present work during the Poster Session or Flash Talks.
questions.sponsor_answer: Please contact us at data@icmc.usp.br or matheoangelo@usp.br with the details of your proposal.

khipu.title: KHIPUx: Spring School on LLMs
khipu.description: Join us on November 15 and 16 for a deep dive into the world of LLMs! Learn in theory and practice how the most famous AI models today work.
khipu.dateDetails: On November 15 and 16, 2025, join us for an immersive experience on Large Language Models, featuring lectures and hands-on minicourses designed to help you learn and apply cutting-edge techniques.

lectures.title: High-level Lectures
lectures.description: Learn from renowned researchers and industry professionals about finetuning and AI agents directly from those who work with these technologies every day.

courses.title: Hands-on Minicourses
courses.description: Develop practical applications using the most advanced technologies available in the AI ecosystem.

about.title: ABOUT THE EVENT
about.description: KHIPU is the main Latin American gathering focused on Artificial Intelligence (AI). Its mission is to strengthen the research and development community in AI and Machine Learning (ML) throughout Latin America. KHIPUx supports local organizations across the region by promoting initiatives that expand access to cutting-edge AI knowledge.
about.details: The Spring School on LLMs aims to disseminate state-of-the-art knowledge in Artificial Intelligence, with a special focus on Large Language Models (LLMs) and multi-agent systems. The event brings together both theoretical and practical perspectives on the most recent advances in LLM technologies.

historyCTA.text: Want to learn more about KHIPU’s history?

saturday.title: Strategies for Adapting LLMs
saturday.speaker: Matheus Jorge - Tractian
saturday.description: This talk will explore techniques such as In-Context Learning, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), and Finetuning, highlighting practical applications, challenges, and real-world use cases in industry settings.

saturday.title: Minicourse – Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
saturday.speaker: Renato Moraes Silva - ICMC/USP
saturday.description: A hands-on minicourse where participants will learn practical RAG techniques used to enhance the effectiveness of LLMs. The session includes foundational concepts and essential tools for implementing RAG pipelines.

sunday.title: Ailo: Understanding How to Build a Large-Scale AI Agent
sunday.speaker: Daniel Wolbert - iFood
sunday.description: Daniel Wolbert will share insights on building large-scale AI agents, discussing technical challenges and best practices for creating robust and efficient systems designed for complex, high-demand environments.

sunday.title: Minicourse – Building Multi-Agent AI Systems from Scratch
sunday.speaker: Moacir Ponti - Professor, ICMC/USP
sunday.description: This minicourse will teach participants how to design and implement multi-agent systems using modern AI techniques. Topics include core concepts, agent architectures, coordination strategies, and hands-on exercises with widely used professional tools.

speakers.title: SPEAKERS OF THE SPRING SCHOOL ON LLMs

list.name: Matheus Jorge
list.bio: Matheus Jorge holds a degree in Computer Engineering from the School of Engineering of São Carlos (EESC) and the Institute of Mathematics and Computer Sciences (ICMC) at the University of São Paulo (USP). He has worked professionally with Machine Learning and Data Science since his undergraduate studies, developing large-scale AI solutions. He is currently the Head of Machine Learning Engineering at Tractian, where he leads the team responsible for designing, developing, and deploying systems based on Large Language Models (LLMs) and other machine learning technologies. His work involves applied research, production pipelines for AI models, and the development of intelligent systems for industrial environments. His interests include language models, ML engineering, and AI systems for large-scale operations.

list.name: Daniel Wolbert
list.bio: Daniel Wolbert is a Data & AI Lead at iFood, where he leads Data Science and Artificial Intelligence teams focused on developing scalable solutions for high-demand environments. He has over eight years of experience in the industry, working on the design, implementation, and operation of intelligent systems applied to technology and service sectors. Throughout his career, Daniel has specialized in machine learning, intelligent agent development, data engineering, and AI architectures for digital products. His work spans model strategy, infrastructure design, and production pipeline oversight, with emphasis on performance, reliability, and user impact. His interests include multi-agent systems, model scalability, observability, and practical applications of AI in enterprise settings.

list.name: Moacir Ponti
list.bio: Moacir Ponti is an Associate Professor at the Institute of Mathematics and Computer Sciences at the University of São Paulo (ICMC-USP). His research focuses on Machine Learning, Computer Vision, and Artificial Intelligence. He has authored more than 60 publications in high-impact international venues and is ranked among the top 2% most influential scientists worldwide according to Stanford University. Beyond academia, Moacir is also a Machine Learning specialist at Mercado Livre, contributing to the development of large-scale AI solutions. His expertise spans data modeling, intelligent systems, LLMs, and modern deep learning methods, with emphasis on both applied research and real-world applications.

list.name: Renato Moraes Silva
list.bio: Renato Moraes Silva is an Associate Professor at the Institute of Mathematics and Computer Sciences at the University of São Paulo (ICMC-USP). He is a member of the Center for Artificial Intelligence at USP (C4AI-USP) and the Interinstitutional Center for Computational Linguistics (NILC), two of Brazil’s leading research centers in AI and Natural Language Processing. His research spans language models, information retrieval systems, NLP, and deep learning, with contributions to applied research and professional training in these areas. Renato has experience in large-scale collaborative projects involving academia and industry, focusing on the development and evaluation of modern AI methods for language understanding and generation. His interests include LLMs, search systems, RAG, text representation, and deep learning architectures for NLP.

questions.language: Will the event be in Portuguese?
questions.language_answer: Yes, the entire event will be held in Portuguese. To make the content accessible to people from other countries, recorded sessions will be available with English subtitles.
questions.location: Where will the event take place?
questions.location_answer: The event will take place at ICMC - USP. The location of each activity can be checked in the event schedule. Additionally, lectures, minicourses, and Flash Talks will be streamed live on the Data YouTube channel.
questions.certificate: Is there a certificate of participation?
questions.certificate_answer: Yes, participants who register for the event and attend at least three lectures or minicourses will receive a certificate. There will also be special certificates for those who present work during the Poster Session or Flash Talks.
questions.sponsor: How can I become a sponsor?
questions.sponsor_answer: Please contact us at data@icmc.usp.br or matheoangelo@usp.br with details about your proposal.
